awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Future Storm-Resolving Configurations of Community Earth System Model (CESM); Fort Collins, Colorado; Two days in April 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a workshop on the topic of global storm resolving configurations of the Community Earth System Model (CESM).  CESM includes a full representation of the earth's climate system, including component models for the atmosphere, ocean, land surface, sea ice, and ice sheets.  Earth system models like CESM simulate wind, temperature, humidity, and other atmospheric variables on grids in which the grid spacing is too coarse (generally at least 15km) to simulate convection, meaning the overturning atmospheric motions seen in thunderstorms.  While it is very difficult to simulate the full range of convective motions, models with grid spacings of a few kilometers (say 3km) are able to simulate the evolution of mesoscale convective systems (MCSs), the large thunderstorm systems that occur over the central US and in other parts of the world.  Thus there is interest in developing configurations of CESM with the necessary high resolution and enhanced dynamics and physics required to enable simulation of MCSs and other forms of organized convection.  The workshop brings together model developers and users who are interested in the development and use of such configurations.

The broader impacts of the workshop come from the desirability of models which are better able to represent weather and climate processes that have substantial impacts on human activities.  For instance much of the extreme precipitation in the US comes from MCSs, which are also responsible for hailstorms and tornado outbreaks.  More specifically, the workshop benefits the broad community of users and developers of CESM, which is the only earth system developed by and for the global climate research community. Funds from this award will support travel expenses for students and early-career scientists attending the meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As part of our efforts to build community, EarthWorks was funded by the NSF Climate and Large-Scale Dynamics program to host a two-day Workshop that was tightly focused on the development and applications of global storm-resolving models that are based on the Community Earth System Model. The purpose of the workshop was to bring together model developers and model users who were interested in models that have horizontal grid spacings on the order of 4 km or finer. Both coupled atmosphere-ocean models and atmosphere-only models (both with land surface models) were included in the scope of the workshop. The applications of the models include studies related to both weather and climate. 

The workshop occurred on the CSU Atmospheric Science campus from May 16-17, 2023. There were nearly 50 participants approximately equally divided between CSU faculty and students, faculty and students from other universities, and NCAR researchers. There were also a few participants from the private sector (e.g., NVIDIA). Approximately 25% of the attendees were students and early career researchers. The agenda of the Workshop included sessions devoted to model formulation, model physics, weather and climate applications, data, and computational science. 

The workshop began with plenary presentations. Several speakers discussed pathways for CESM to reach storm-resolving capabilities, including EarthWorks (Dave Randall, CSU, PI EarthWorks), a newly proposed effort to integrate  DOE’s Spectral Element non-hydrostatic dynamical core into CESM (Christiane Jablonowski, U. Michigan), which would include close collaboration with EarthWorks on modeling infrastructure and GPU-ready physics (Bill Skamarock, NCAR, co-I EarthWorks), and current CESM capabilities with variable-resolution grids down to 15 km over regions including the Arctic, U.S., the North Atlantic, and South America (Adam Herrington, NCAR). 

Other speakers discussed both weather (Falko Judt, NCAR) and climate (Justin Small, NCAR) applications of global storm-resolving models, including applications of the DOE SCREAM model (Ruby Leung, DOE). Speakers also addressed data (Brian Mederois, NCAR, co-I EarthWorks) and computational challenges (Rich Loft, AreandDee LLC, co-I EarthWorks).

Much of the workshop was spent in working groups, which focused on challenges and opportunities associated with dynamical cores, physics, weather and climate applications, and data and computational issues. The final session of the workshop featured a panel discussion of plenary speakers and working group leads on the ways forward based on questions and perspectives from other workshop participants. 

The workshop was effective in creating and enhancing synergies among the developers and users of high-resolution coupled models based on the CESM. It was successful in bringing together researchers who are, at present, largely disconnected, and thus was a first step in facilitating coordination and enhanced collaboration, as well as sharing lessons learned and best practices.

The organizing committee met after the conclusion of the workshop and developed an outline of a paper that will be submitted to the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society later this year. The paper will include discussions of the scientific applications of global storm resolving models, the role of such models in a modeling hierarchy, current high resolution modeling efforts and future directions, challenges and opportunities in model development and use, and how the community could be organized around such modeling efforts.
